page.title: 01SOUTHOE AND DIDDINGTON
page.content: Both villages rise gently from the Ouse Valley. Agriculture is the main land use, especially arable crops. Gravel workings will soon alter landscape near the river. Southoe has expanded greatly in the last twenty years and is now a cummuter dormitory village. Diddington has a decreased population (1841, 216, 1985, 86) mainly due to smaller families. Active woodland management is replacing trees in an area ravaged by dutch elm disease and general neglect of trees. A new footpath scheme has opened up the area to walkers.
